bestBHT.bht: When the sun was up and began to shine out hot, the plants lacking sufficient moisture were scorched and withered away. Believers too need both the light of the Gospel and the sustenance of God's Word to flourish, just as plants require both sunshine and moisture. The Gospel has the power to soften hearts and bring life or harden them and bring death. It is crucial to understand that this does not indicate the apostasy of true believers but rather emphasizes the importance of deep roots in faith.

Henry Alford: 6.] root = “moisture” Luke. If the one could have struck down, it would have found the other.
Philip Schaff: Plants need both sunshine and moisture; they get the first from their growth above ground, the second from their growth below ground.
Archibald T. Robertson: The sun was risen (ηλιου ανατειλαντος). Genitive absolute. "The sun having sprung up" also, same verb except the absence of εξ (ανατελλω, εξανατελλω).
John Gill: And when the sun was up,.... Some time, and its heat was increasing, and it began to shine out hot, and beat with some vehemency and strength; which may denote some sore temptation, or severe affliction, or fiery trial of persecution and tribulation;
the Gospel is to the hardening of some, and softening of others; to the one it is the savour of life unto life, and to the other the savour of death unto death
This is no instance of the apostasy of real saints, or any proof of true believers falling away finally and totally

bhtAttempts.bht: When the sun rose and began to shine out hot, the plants that were not rooted deeply enough with sufficient moisture were quickly scorched and withered away. Just as plants need both sunshine and moisture for their growth, so too do believers need both the light of the Gospel and the sustenance of God's Word to flourish in their faith. The Gospel has the power to both soften and harden hearts, bringing life to some and death to others. It is important to remember, however, that this verse is not indicative of the apostasy of true believers, but rather speaks to the consequences of lacking deep roots in faith.

When the sun was up and began to shine out hot, the plants lacking sufficient moisture were scorched and withered away. Believers too need both the light of the Gospel and the sustenance of God's Word to flourish, just as plants require both sunshine and moisture. The Gospel has the power to soften hearts and bring life or harden them and bring death. It is crucial to understand that this does not indicate the apostasy of true believers but rather emphasizes the importance of deep roots in faith.

As the sun rose and its heat increased, plants without sufficient moisture were scorched and withered away. Similarly, believers need both the light of the Gospel and the sustenance of God's Word to thrive. The Gospel has the power to soften hearts, leading to life, or harden them, resulting in death. It is crucial to remember that this does not imply the apostasy of genuine believers, but rather underscores the significance of establishing deep roots in faith.

As the sun was up and began to shine out hot, the plants lacking sufficient moisture were scorched and withered. Believers need both the light of the Gospel and the sustenance of God's Word to flourish, similar to how plants require both sunshine and moisture. The Gospel has the power to soften hearts, bringing life to some, and harden hearts, bringing death to others. While this verse does not imply the apostasy of true believers, it emphasizes the importance of establishing deep roots in faith.

As the sun rose and its heat intensified, plants without sufficient moisture were scorched and withered away. Similarly, believers require both the light of the Gospel and the sustenance of God's Word to thrive. The Gospel has the power to soften hearts, bringing life to some, and harden hearts, bringing death to others. It is crucial to understand that this does not signify the apostasy of true believers, but rather emphasizes the importance of deep roots in faith.
